messages: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:01): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: for r1848, there are a couple places where it seems like the only change made was to change the order of some citations -- "[RFC2109] [RFC2965]" instead of "[RFC2965] [RFC2109]"
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:01): wondering what the significance of that change is meant to be
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:01): yes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:01): none, just wanted it in numerical order
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:06): the checkin comment made it seems like more was happening
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:06): I landed an initial version of the AC draft we agreed upon at the Seattle F2F: http://dev.w3.org/2006/waf/access-control/
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:07): It doesn't have the headers/methods proposal included yet, though there are comments in the source regarding that
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:09): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: cool. that was pretty fast work
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:09): about that checkin, more did happen -
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:09): http://people.w3.org/mike/diffs/html5/spec/Overview.1.1037.html#sandboxCookies
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:10): just that it added "or later specifications" to "RFC 2109 section 4.3.4. or later specifications"
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (12:10): is there any writeup about what happened at that meeting?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:10): true

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:12): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427, http://www.w3.org/2008/07/01-wam-minutes.html and http://www.w3.org/2008/07/02-wam-minutes.html if you have W3C Member access
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:13): http://www.w3.org/2008/07/03-wam-minutes.html seems to have even more limited rights, a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:13): they should become public within a few weeks (hopefully less)

f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (12:15): is there a good resource for "onload events"? i've looked at a few different libraries and the browser specific hacks aside there seems a number of ways to do it: onload. window.load, DOMContentLoaded, document.readyState. I'm assuming here I should have the DOM ready for an AJAX call.
f4dfad803df83144a5be86d9bca87678 (12:16): this is for a mobile AJAX test case: http://dev.w3.org/cvsweb/2008/mobile-test/xmlhttprequest.js
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:16): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: I just changed http://www.w3.org/2008/07/03-wam-minutes.html to member-viewable
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (12:17): schepers was there? huh
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:17): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: for me, it was particularly nice to finally meet Jonas Sicking
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:18): 03 was the day we made descisions on all the drastic changes quite early in the morning
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:19): goes food shopping before falling asleep

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:19): 042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427: btw, I went to a FF3 release party here in Tokyo a couple weeks back. They showed a video with clips from a bunch of Mozilla developers talking about their favorite feature in FF3
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:19): including you
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:19): so that was cool too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:23): Julien Chaffraix's started checking in code changes to support XBL2 in Webkit
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:24): http://trac.webkit.org/search?q=jchaffraix
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (12:30): how long were these AC meetings?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:30): theoretically 9-5 tuesday-thursday
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:31): in practice, 1pm-5pm tuesday, 11pm-5pm wednesday, 11pm-5pm friday
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:31): though everything after 3pm on friday seems to be missing from the minutes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:31): (which is unfortunate as i left at 3pm)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (12:31): we adjourned around that point
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:45): it's 11PM and not 11AM?
042dd99eb0ff8653814e445ca0093427 (12:45): I'm sure he meant 11am
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:45): i meant am
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:48): good, I already find it slightly quirky that it's 12PM for midday (iirc), but this would be even more odd
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:49): the whole am/pm thing is silly imho
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:49): what's wrong with 24h clocks
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:49): Europe generally uses 24h clocks for notation
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:49): well, the Netherlands :p
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:50): i know, i'm european :-)
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (12:53): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e, which country are you from originally?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (12:54): 11:59:59.999 is clearly AM, 12:00:00.001 is clearly PM, so it makes sense that 12:00:00.000 is PM because it shares most of its digits with nearby PM times
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:54): switzerland
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (12:54): hence the .ch
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (12:57): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, true, I suppose I expect 0-11 rather than 12-11
